a7f8dbf70ba0.original_description: The Met Office says that 2025 is likely to be the UK's hottest year since records began.

71109525c494.title: 'Year of octopus' declared after warmer seas lead to record UK numbers
71109525c494.summary: Год осьминога объявлен в Великобритании после рекордного увеличения численности этих моллюсков, вызванного потеплением моря. По данным Wildlife Trusts, количество наблюдений достигло максимума с 1950 года.
71109525c494.original_description: The Wildlife Trusts say its is 'flabbergasted' by the sighting of the highest number of octopuses since 1950

7d701a8dcb8c.title: Hen cages and pig farrowing crates face ban
7d701a8dcb8c.summary: Правительство Великобритании планирует запретить клетки для кур и станки для опороса свиней в рамках масштабной реформы благосостояния животных. Эта инициатива названа крупнейшими изменениями в этой области за последнее поколение.
7d701a8dcb8c.original_description: The government says its animal welfare strategy will bring "the biggest reforms in a generation".

f911497fcaf1.title: Government rolls back nature protections to boost housing
f911497fcaf1.summary: Правительство отменило часть мер по охране природы в рамках ключевой политики в области биоразнообразия, чтобы стимулировать строительство жилья. Критики опасаются, что эти изменения могут замедлить восстановление природных экосистем.
f911497fcaf1.original_description: Critics say government changes to a flagship biodiversity policy could stall nature recovery.

2ae3cecb8788.title: Spain's commitment to renewable energy may be in doubt
2ae3cecb8788.summary: Правящая в Испании партия ослаблена политически, что ставит под сомнение её приверженность развитию возобновляемой энергетики. Оппозиция выступает за увеличение использования ископаемого топлива, что может повлиять на энергетическую политику страны.
2ae3cecb8788.original_description: The current government is politically weakened and the opposition wants more use of fossil fuels.

088d238a750e.title: Cats became our companions much later than you think
088d238a750e.summary: Кошки стали домашними животными значительно позже, чем считалось ранее. Исследования показывают, что их приручение произошло не в Древнем Египте, а в более поздний период, когда они сами постепенно начали селиться рядом с людьми.
088d238a750e.original_description: In true feline style, cats took their time in deciding when and where to join us on the sofa.

4d4298b50bdf.title: Brazil's Amazon rainforest at risk as key protection under threat
4d4298b50bdf.summary: Фермеры Бразилии требуют отмены запрета на выращивание сои на вырубленных участках Амазонии, что может привести к ускорению обезлесения. Критики предупреждают, что отмена ограничений поставит под угрозу усилия по охране крупнейшего в мире тропического леса.
4d4298b50bdf.original_description: Brazilian farmers want to end a ban on planting soya on cleared land, which critics say would spur deforestation.

9857e1b2c35b.title: Landmark deal to cut global shipping emissions in tatters after US pressure

7abe8ce4d41d.original_description: Australia's rainforests are the first in the world to make the "concerning" switch, say scientists.

4e01e8ff3693.summary: Сейсмические датчики, предназначенные для регистрации землетрясений, могут использоваться для отслеживания падения космического мусора. Вибрации и акустические ударные волны от сгорающих обломков позволяют точно определять место их падения. Эта технология поможет заранее предупреждать людей о потенциальных опасностях.

Однако научное сообщество пока не пришло к единому мнению, и доказательства этого явления остаются предметом дискуссий.
2e03a64aa253.original_description: Rising Arctic temperatures and melting sea ice could be causing cold air to flow into the Northern Hemisphere. But not all scientists agree.

5e836440fb89.title: Vaccine Panel Chair Says Polio and Other Shots Should Be Optional, Rejecting Decades of Science

Он предложил сделать вакцинацию необязательной, что противоречит многолетним научным данным о её эффективности для общественного здоровья.

Researchers say artificial intelligence system matches human expert classification about 90% of the time

Experts have created an app that uses artificial intelligence to identify dinosaurs from the footprints left behind after they stomped across the land tens of millions of years ago.

“When we find a dinosaur footprint, we try to do the Cinderella thing and find the foot that matches the slipper,” said Prof Steve Brusatte, a co-author of the work, from the University of Edinburgh

ca05958e0508.title: Spider monkeys found to share ‘insider knowledge’ to help locate best food
ca05958e0508.summary:
Researchers observed the primates switching social groups and passing information on where to find the ripest fruit

Spider monkeys share tips about where to find food by changing their social groups in a “clever system for sharing insider knowledge”, research has shown.

They were observed to frequently switch subgroups of three or more individuals in a way that enabled them to share information about the location of fruit trees and timing of when they would ripen.

970c05e8d9da.title: SpaceX lines up Wall Street banks as Musk eyes blockbuster IPO
970c05e8d9da.summary:
US aerospace tech company reportedly held talks last year over private share sale that values business at $800bn

Elon Musk’s SpaceX is reportedly lining up four Wall Street banks to help the company list on the stock market as investors prepare for an expected rush of US tech listings.

SpaceX is considering Bank of America, JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley for leading roles in an initial public offering, according to the Financial Times and Reuters.

792cd9f2352e.title: Fake weight-loss medication in tablet form could flood Britain, experts warn
792cd9f2352e.summary: Эксперты предупреждают, что запуск таблетированных форм препаратов для похудения в Великобритании может привести к появлению массовых подделок. Мошенники, вероятно, попытаются воспользоваться тем, что таблетки сложнее контролировать, чем инъекции. Для предотвращения рисков для здоровья граждан требуется ужесточение регулирования и усиление мер по борьбе с контрафактной продукцией.
792cd9f2352e.original_description:
Better regulation and enforcement urged before launch of oral treatments, which criminals are likely to try to exploit

Experts are warning that fake weight-loss treatments could become more prevalent as tablet forms of the medications, currently available only via injections in the UK, are launched.

They say stronger regulation and enforcement are needed to prevent fraudsters from cashing in on tablets which will be easier to counterfeit.

a70d68310fce.title: Weight-loss drugs do nothing to address the troubled relationships we have with our bodies | Susie Orbach
a70d68310fce.summary:
The food, beauty and pharmaceutical industries poison our self-image. GLP-1 drugs will only make them richer – and strengthen the hold they have over us

Fifty years ago, I started thinking about the demand for women to look a certain way and the rebellions against the narrow ways in which we were supposed to display (and not display) our bodies. For a while, there was a conversation about the strictures. Some young women refused to conform. Some women risked being in the bodies they had

441141e86e12.title: Has the world entered an era of ‘water bankruptcy’? – podcast
441141e86e12.summary: Last week, a UN report declared that the world has entered an era of ‘global water bankruptcy’ with many human water systems past the point at which they can be restored to former levels. To find out what this could look like, Madeleine Finlay speaks to the Guardian’s diplomatic editor, Patrick Wintour, who has been reporting on Iran’s severe water crisis. And Mohammad Shamsudduha, professor of water crisis and risk reduction in the department of risk and disaster reduction at University Coll

3e410d302ab2.title: How to sleep well in 2026 – podcast
3e410d302ab2.summary: В подкасте обсуждаются проблемы сна, включая влияние менопаузы, сонный паралич и связь с деменцией. Эксперт также даёт рекомендации по улучшению качества сна в 2026 году.
3e410d302ab2.original_description:
Ian Sample puts listeners’ questions on sleep to Dr Allie Hare, consultant physician in respiratory and sleep medicine at Guy’s and St Thomas’ hospitals and president of the British Sleep Society. They cover why women experience sleep disturbance during the menopause, why sleep paralysis affects some people more than others, and what scientists know about the link between sleep and dementia. Hare also gives her top tips for getting better sleep in 2026

9e785b2eaea0.title: The man taking over the Large Hadron Collider – only to switch it off
9e785b2eaea0.summary: Марк Томпсон, профессор Кембриджского университета, становится новым генеральным директором CERN. Он возглавит организацию с целью построения нового, более мощного коллайдера для замены Большого адронного коллайдера. Это решение означает, что при его участии старый коллайдер будет выключен ради исследований более глубоких тайн вселенной.
9e785b2eaea0.original_description:
Next head of Cern backs massive replacement for world’s largest machine to investigate mysteries of the universe

Mark Thomson, a professor of experimental particle physics at the University of Cambridge, has landed one of the most coveted jobs in global science. But it is hard not to wonder, when looked at from a certain angle, whether he has taken one for the team.

On 1 January, Thomson takes over as the director general of Cern, the multi-Nobel prizewinning nuclear physics labor

7adf073dbf7d.title: Strong v swole: the surprising truth about building muscle
7adf073dbf7d.summary:
Traditional bodybuilding advice has been to push workouts to the point of failure, and that soreness is an indicator of effectiveness. But recent studies show there’s another way

Until pretty recently, the conventional wisdom about building muscle was that it worked via a system you might think of as “tear and repair” – the idea being that working out causes microtears in the muscle fibres, which trigger the body’s repair processes, encouraging the muscles to come back bigger and strong

1f32e9f06b24.title: A century-old Stonehenge mystery may finally be solved
1f32e9f06b24.summary: Scientists have found compelling new evidence that humans, not glaciers, brought Stonehenge’s bluestones to the site. Using advanced mineral analysis, researchers searched nearby river sediments for signs glaciers once passed through the area—and found none. That missing signature strongly suggests the stones were intentionally moved by people. How they did it remains a mystery, but ice is now largely ruled out.

34d93a5ab644.title: The type of carbs you eat may affect dementia risk
34d93a5ab644.summary: Carbohydrates don’t just fuel the body—they may also influence how the brain ages. A large long-term study found that diets high in fast-acting carbs that rapidly raise blood sugar were linked to a higher risk of dementia. People who ate more low-glycemic foods like fruit, legumes, and whole grains had a noticeably lower risk of Alzheimer’s. The quality of carbs, not just the amount, appears to matter for brain health.

a59534aeda4b.title: These common food preservatives may be linked to cancer
a59534aeda4b.summary: A large French study tracking more than 100,000 people over a decade has found that higher consumption of certain food preservatives—commonly found in processed foods and drinks—is linked to a modestly higher cancer risk. While many preservatives showed no association, several widely used ones, including potassium sorbate, sulfites, sodium nitrite, and potassium nitrate, were tied to increased risks of overall cancer and specific types such as breast and prostate cancer.

8a0556c9875a.title: Scientists finally explain Earth’s strangest fossils
8a0556c9875a.summary: The Ediacara Biota are some of the strangest fossils ever found—soft-bodied organisms preserved in remarkable detail where preservation shouldn’t be possible. Scientists now think their survival in sandstone came from unusual ancient seawater chemistry that created clay “cements” around their bodies after burial. This process captured delicate shapes that would normally vanish. The finding helps clarify how complex life emerged before the Cambrian Explosion.

23caf84e5e4f.title: This discovery could let bones benefit from exercise without moving
23caf84e5e4f.summary: Researchers have discovered a biological switch that explains why movement keeps bones strong. The protein senses physical activity and pushes bone marrow stem cells to build bone instead of storing fat, slowing age-related bone loss. By targeting this “exercise sensor,” scientists believe they could create drugs that mimic exercise at the molecular level. The approach could protect fragile bones in people who are unable to stay active.

8250c6d5fa75.title: Scientists may have been wrong about what causes asthma
8250c6d5fa75.summary: Asthma may not be driven by the molecules scientists have blamed for decades. Researchers have identified “pseudo leukotrienes,” inflammation-triggering compounds formed by uncontrolled free-radical reactions rather than normal enzymes. These molecules were found at much higher levels in people with asthma, closely tracking how severe their symptoms were. The finding hints at a new way to treat asthma by preventing the inflammatory spark instead of blocking its aftermath.

2cb2e99dca55.title: Keto diet weight loss may come with a hidden cost
2cb2e99dca55.summary: A long-term study found that while a ketogenic diet prevented weight gain, it also triggered major metabolic problems. Mice developed fatty liver disease, abnormal blood fats, and an impaired ability to control blood sugar—especially after reintroducing carbohydrates. Male mice were hit hardest, showing severe liver damage. The results suggest keto’s benefits may come with hidden risks over time.

4abcdb97c49f.title: Strange white rocks on Mars hint at millions of years of rain
4abcdb97c49f.summary: Bright white rocks spotted by NASA’s Perseverance rover are rewriting what we thought we knew about ancient Mars. These aluminum-rich clays, called kaolinite, usually form on Earth only after millions of years of heavy rainfall in warm, humid environments—conditions similar to tropical rainforests. Their presence on today’s cold, dry Mars suggests the planet once had abundant rain, flowing water, and possibly lush oases long ago. Even more puzzling, the rocks are scattered across the landscape w

6987cf38e187.title: Scientists found a survival switch inside brain cells
6987cf38e187.summary: Findings could create new opportunities to treat and study neurodegenerative diseasesScientists discovered that sugar metabolism plays a surprising role in whether injured neurons collapse or cling to life. By activating internal protective programs, certain metabolic changes can temporarily slow neurodegeneration—hinting at new ways to help the brain defend itself.

42ec124286d0.title: Scientists say quantum tech has reached its transistor moment
42ec124286d0.summary: Quantum technology has reached a turning point, echoing the early days of modern computing. Researchers say functional quantum systems now exist, but scaling them into truly powerful machines will require major advances in engineering and manufacturing. By comparing different quantum platforms, the study reveals both impressive progress and steep challenges ahead. History suggests the payoff could be enormous—but not immediate.

50d4d3291393.title: A hidden magnetic order could unlock superconductivity
50d4d3291393.summary: Physicists have discovered that hidden magnetic order plays a key role in the pseudogap, a puzzling state of matter that appears just before certain materials become superconductors. Using an ultra-cold quantum simulator, the team found that even when magnetism seems disrupted, subtle and universal magnetic patterns persist beneath the surface. These patterns closely track the temperature at which the pseudogap forms, suggesting magnetism may help set the stage for superconductivity.

c08a7cca9742.title: Obesity and high blood pressure may directly cause dementia
c08a7cca9742.summary: A new genetic study suggests that obesity and high blood pressure may play a direct role in causing dementia, not just increasing the risk. By analyzing data from large populations in Denmark and the U.K., researchers found strong evidence that higher body weight can damage brain health over time, especially when it leads to elevated blood pressure. Much of the dementia risk appeared to be tied to vascular damage in the brain, which affects blood flow and cognitive function.

662811195a25.title: A dying star’s final breath glows in a new Webb image of the Helix Nebula
662811195a25.summary: Webb’s latest image of the Helix Nebula reveals a dramatic close-up of a dying star shedding its outer layers. The detailed view highlights glowing knots of gas shaped by fast-moving stellar winds colliding with older material. Changes in color trace a shift from scorching hot gas near the center to cooler regions farther out. The scene captures how stellar death helps supply the building blocks for future worlds.

931c08154030.title: Distant entangled atoms acting as one sensor deliver stunning precision
931c08154030.summary: Researchers have demonstrated that quantum entanglement can link atoms across space to improve measurement accuracy. By splitting an entangled group of atoms into separate clouds, they were able to measure electromagnetic fields more precisely than before. The technique takes advantage of quantum connections acting at a distance. It could enhance tools such as atomic clocks and gravity sensors.

8d733cf32ab8.title: Your fireplace may be doing more harm than you think
8d733cf32ab8.summary: Home fireplaces and wood stoves are quietly driving a large share of winter air pollution, even though only a small number of households rely on wood heat. Researchers found that wood smoke accounts for over one-fifth of Americans’ winter exposure to dangerous fine particles linked to heart disease and early death. Much of this pollution drifts into cities, where it disproportionately harms people of color. Reducing wood burning could deliver major public health benefits.

ecb9a87c42fc.title: The magnetic secret inside steel finally explained
ecb9a87c42fc.summary: For years, scientists noticed that magnetic fields could improve steel, but no one knew exactly why. New simulations reveal that magnetism changes how iron atoms behave, making it harder for carbon atoms to slip through the metal. This slows diffusion at the atomic level and alters steel’s internal structure. The insight could lead to more efficient, lower-energy ways to make stronger steel.

6811c0ba41eb.title: New DNA analysis rewrites the story of the Beachy Head Woman
6811c0ba41eb.summary: A Roman-era skeleton discovered in southern England has finally given up her secrets after more than a decade of debate. Known as the Beachy Head Woman, she was once thought to have roots in sub-Saharan Africa or the Mediterranean—an idea that sparked global attention. But new, high-quality DNA analysis paints a different picture: she was most likely a local woman from Roman Britain.

194c6b968590.title: A hidden genetic war is unfolding inside your DNA
194c6b968590.summary: Our genome isn’t as peaceful as it looks—some DNA elements are constantly trying to disrupt it. Scientists studying fruit flies discovered that key proteins protecting chromosome ends must evolve rapidly to counter these internal threats. When these proteins fall out of sync, chromosomes fuse and cells die. The work reveals how essential biological systems survive by constantly reinventing themselves.

9b89ced4aec4.title: Alzheimer’s may trick the brain into erasing its own memories
9b89ced4aec4.summary: Alzheimer’s may destroy memory by flipping a single molecular switch that tells neurons to prune their own connections. Researchers found that both amyloid beta and inflammation converge on the same receptor, triggering synapse loss. Surprisingly, neurons aren’t passive victims—they actively respond to these signals. Targeting this receptor could offer a new way to protect memory beyond current amyloid-focused drugs.

2677dee6266d.title: A strange in-between state of matter is finally observed
2677dee6266d.summary: When materials become just one atom thick, melting no longer follows the familiar rules. Instead of jumping straight from solid to liquid, an unusual in-between state emerges, where atomic positions loosen like a liquid but still keep some solid-like order. Scientists at the University of Vienna have now captured this elusive “hexatic” phase in real time by filming an ultra-thin silver iodide crystal as it melted inside a protective graphene sandwich.

A global shortage of nearly a million midwives is leaving pregnant women without the basic care needed to prevent harm, including the deaths of mothers and babies, according to new research.

Almost half the shortage was in Africa, where nine in 10 women lived in a country without enough midwives, the researchers said.

QKThr, an obscure cut from Aphex Twin’s 2001 album, Drukqs, sounds like an ambient experiment recorded on a historic pirate ship. Shaky fingers caress the keys of an accordion to create an uncanny tone; clustered chords cry out, subdued but mighty, before scuttling back into dreamy nothingness.
